page.title: 03The Guildhall
page.content: This is a large timber-framed building in the Market Square.It was built in 1528 by the Guild of Corpus Christi for people to come together to sell wool. The porch has carved doorposts and inside there are large fire-places and wide,carved beams.The National Trust owns the Guildhall now and runs it as a museum.In the cellar you can see how barrels were made.There is an old fire-engine.Upstairs a display shows how Lavenham Blue Cloth was made and many other interesting things. The building was only used as a Guildhall for about 30 years.It has been a prison,a meeting-place for clothiers,a work-house,a nursery school and a club for American airmen during the war.The distinctive pattern of marks on the front wall was probably caused by children sharpening slate pencils.
